Christina Patricola is an atmospheric scientist at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab and the author of a study published in Nature today.
We're already starting to see that climate change has enhanced tropical cyclone rainfall.
Tropical cyclone rainfall is scientist speak for hurricane rain.
Patricola and colleagues looked at three super destructive hurricanes - Katrina, Irma and Maria.
They created a model for how much rain would've fallen if there was no climate change and compared it to what actually happened.
We're finding that the total storm rainfall has increased by about 5 to 10 percent.
That's 5 to 10 percent more rain in New Orleans, in Florida, in Puerto Rico.
The extra water contributed to death and destruction from all three storms.

He wasn't involved in Patricola's study, but he says it's the latest confirmation that humans are making hurricanes worse.

Imagine Hurricane Harvey starts in the Gulf of Mexico and blows across Texas.

So the way I would think about it is that the buildings stopped the air from being able to move forwards, away from the ocean, through the grasslands that would've been there if Houston hadn't been built, and further into Texas.
They sort of stopped the air in that general area.
And the air has nowhere to go but either around the buildings or up.
The buildings force extra air up into the colder parts of the atmosphere, and that generates more rain because the air coming from the Gulf of Mexico is hot and moist.
When moist air touches a cold surface or is in contact with cold, it will tend to form droplets, as the water does on the outside of a glass.
And so that's how the rain is formed.
So hot, moist air hits buildings.
It goes up, condenses into drops and falls as rain.
The more air that you raise up, in general, the more rain that you will have.
